Question_1.Context: A pneumatic dispenser driven by a flexible membrane with a capacitive-type sensor using an SLA-type 3D printer was fabricated.
Question_1.Question: What is the approximate range of a single droplet that could be ejected from the 200-μm-diameter nozzle?
Question_1.Source: It was confirmed that a single droplet in the range of approximately 400–450 nL could be ejected from the currently processed 200-μm-diameter nozzle.

Question_2.Context: The deformation varied according to the magnitude and time of the positive pressure applied to the membrane sensor.
Question_2.Question: How does the deformation of the membrane vary?
Question_2.C: It varies with the magnitude and time of positive pressure.
Question_2.Source: The deformation varied according to the magnitude and time of the positive pressure applied to the membrane sensor.

Question_3.Context: The base capacitance-to-digital converter (CDC) value decreased when the inlet pressure was removed.
Question_3.Question: What happened to the base CDC value when the inlet pressure was removed?
Question_3.Source: The base capacitance-to-digital converter (CDC) value decreased when the inlet pressure was removed.

Question_4.Context: The dispenser was designed and fabricated at a size suitable for printing using a stereolithography (SLA)-type 3D printer.
Question_4.Question: What type of 3D printer was used for fabricating the dispenser?
Question_4.Source: The dispenser was designed and fabricated at a size suitable for printing using a stereolithography (SLA)-type 3D printer.

Question_5.Context: The dispenser includes an actuation part that controls the pneumatic pressure using a solenoid valve.
Question_5.Question: What part of the dispenser controls the pneumatic pressure?
Question_5.Source: The dispenser includes an actuation part that controls the pneumatic pressure using a solenoid valve.

Question_6.Context: The membrane sensor was manufactured using polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) and consisted of a membrane and supporting block.
Question_6.Question: What material was used for manufacturing the membrane sensor?
Question_6.Source: The membrane sensor was manufactured using polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) and consisted of a membrane and supporting block.

Question_7.Context: The dispenser was completed by fastening/assembling the manufactured parts using bolts.
Question_7.Question: How was the dispenser completed?
Question_7.Source: The dispenser was completed by fastening/assembling the manufactured parts using bolts.

Question_8.Context: The liquid solution delivered at a constant inlet pressure fills the liquid chamber inside the dispenser.
Question_8.Question: What fills the liquid chamber inside the dispenser?
Question_8.Source: The liquid solution delivered at a constant inlet pressure fills the liquid chamber inside the dispenser.

Question_9.Context: The signal for precise control of the solenoid valve is shown in a graph.
Question_9.Question: What is used for precise control of the solenoid valve?
Question_9.Source: The signal for precise control of the solenoid valve is shown in a graph.

Question_10.Context: The volume and velocity of the droplets were quantitatively measured.
Question_10.Question: What aspects of the droplets were quantitatively measured?
Question_10.Source: The volume and velocity of the droplets were quantitatively measured.
